chapter_1_Introductory Chapter.text: Variables.
For the same reason I have not carried the discussion of the and functions further.

Among the minor helps to simplicity is the use of zero subscripts to indicate decreasing series in the Landen Transformation, and of numerical subscripts to indicate increasing series. I have adopted the notation of Gudermann, as being more simple than that of Jacobi.

I have made free use of the following works: Jacobi's Fundamenta Nova Theoriæ Func. Ellip.; Houel's Calcul Infinitésimal; Legendre's Traité des Fonctions Elliptiques; Durege's Theorie der Elliptischen Functionen; Hermite's Théorie des Fonctions Elliptiques; Verhulst's Théorie des Functions Elliptiques; Bertrand's Calcul Intégral; Laurent's Théorie des Fonctions Elliptiques; Cayley's Elliptic Functions; Byerly's Integral Calculus; Schlömilch's Compendium der höheren Analysis; Briot et Bouquet's Fonctions Elliptiques.

I have refrained from any reference to the Gudermann or Weierstrass functions as not within the scope of this work, though the Gudermannians might have been interesting examples of verification formulæ. The arithmetico-geometrical mean, the march of the functions, and other interesting investigations have been left out for want of room.
CONTENTS. PAGE Introductory Chapter, 1 Chap. I. Elliptic Integrals, 4 II. Elliptic Functions, 16

Among the minor helps to simplicity is the use of zero subscripts to indicate decreasing series in the Landen Transformation, and of numerical subscripts to indicate increasing Chap. I. Elliptic Integrals, 4

The first step taken in the theory of Elliptic Functions was the determination of a relation between the amplitudes of three functions of either order, such that there should exist an algebraic relation between the three functions themselves of which these were the amplitudes.
In 1761 Euler gave the complete integration of an equation of two terms, each an elliptic function of the first or second order, not separately integrable.
This integration introduced an arbitrary constant in the form of a third function, related to the first two by a given equation between the amplitudes of the three.

In 1775 Landen published his celebrated theorem showing that any arc of a hyperbola may be measured by two arcs of an ellipse, an important element of the theory of Elliptic Functions, but then an isolated result.
The great problem of comparison of Elliptic Functions of different moduli remained unsolved, though Euler, in a measure, exhausted the comparison of functions of the same modulus.

In 1784 Lagrange completed the comparison of Elliptic Functions of different moduli, and for the computation of numerical results leaves little to be desired. The value of a function may be determined by it, in terms of increasing or diminishing moduli, until at length it depends upon a function having a modulus of zero, or unity.

The first step taken in the theory of Elliptic Functions was the determination of a relation between the amplitudes of three functions of either order, such that there should exist an a function may be determined by it, in terms of increasing or diminishing moduli, until at length it depends upon a function having a modulus of zero, or unity.
For all practical purposes this was sufficient.
The enormous task of calculating tables was undertaken by Legendre.
His labors did not end here, however.

There is none of the discoveries of his predecessors which has not received some perfection at his hands; and it was he who first supplied to the whole that connection and arrangement which have made it an independent science.
The theory of Elliptic Integrals remained at a standstill from 1786, the year when Legendre took it up, until the year 1827, when the second volume of his Traité des Fonctions Elliptiques appeared.

Scarcely so, however, when there appeared the researches of Jacobi, a Professor of Mathematics in Königsberg, in the 123d~number of the Journal of Schumacher, and those of Abel, Professor of Mathematics at Christiania, in the 3d~number of Crelle's Journal for 1827.
These publications put the theory of Elliptic Functions upon an entirely new basis.

The researches of Jacobi have for their principal object the development of that general relation of functions of the first order having different moduli, of which the scales of Legrange{Lagrange} and Legendre are particular cases.
Abel treated the Elliptic Integral as a function of its amplitude.
Proceeding from this new point of view, he embraced in his speculations all the principal results of Jacobi.
Euler established an algebraic relation between three functions which have the same moduli, dependent upon a certain relation of their amplitudes.

Abel extended Euler's proposition from three to an indefinite number of functions and from Elliptic Functions to an infinite number of other functions embraced under an indefinite number of classes, of which Elliptic Functions is but one, each class having a division analogous to that of Elliptic Functions into three orders having common properties.

The discovery of Abel is of infinite moment as presenting the first step of approach towards a more complete theory of the infinite class of ultra elliptic functions, destined probably ere long to constitute one of the most important of the branches of transcendental analysis, and to include among the integrals of which it effects the solution some of those which at present arrest the researches of the philosopher in the very elements of physics.

chapter_2_\\Chapter{I}{Elliptic Integral.text: The integration of irrational expressions where X is a rational function of x is fully illustrated in elementary works and depends on logarithms and circular functions.
Integrating irrational expressions containing higher powers of x than the square leads to insurmountable difficulties because the integral depends on elliptic functions.
Elliptic Integrals are the simple integral forms to which all integrals of higher-degree irrational expressions can be reduced.
V = ∫ F(x, R) dx, where F is a rational function of x and R, and R is the square root of Ax⁴ + Bx³ + Cx² + Dx + E with constant coefficients A, B, C, D, E.
Elliptic Integrals are the three typical forms: ∫₀ˣ dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], ∫₀ˣ x² dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], and ∫₀ˣ dx / [(x² + a) √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)]]
All cases of Eq. (1) can be reduced to the three typical forms: ∫₀ˣ dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], ∫₀ˣ x² dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], and ∫₀ˣ dx / [(x² + a) √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)]]
V = ∫ F(X, R) dx
∫₀ˣ dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)]
∫₀ˣ x² dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)]
∫₀ˣ dx / √[(x² + a)(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)]

The integrals ∫₀ˣ dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], ∫₀ˣ x² dx / √[(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)], and ∫₀ˣ dx / √[(x² + a)(1 - x²)(1 - k²x²)] are called elliptic integrals of the first, second, and third order, respectively.
Why they are called Elliptic Integrals will be explained later.
Transcendental functions depending on elliptic integrals are called Elliptic Functions.
V = ∫ (A + B R)/(C + D R) dx, where A, B, C, D are rational integral functions of x
(A + B R)/(C + D R) = (AC - B D R²)/(C² - D² R²) - (AD - CB) R / (C² - D² R²) = N - P(R)
N and P are rational integral functions of x
V = ∫ N dx - ∫ (P / R) dx
V' = ∫ (P / R) dx
The most general form of V can be made to depend upon the expressions V' and N dx
The form N dx is rational and needs no discussion here
P = (G₀ + G₁x + G₂x² + ...) / (H₀ + H₁x + H₂x² + ...) = (G₀ + G₂x² + G₄x⁴ + ... + (G₁ + G₃x² + ...)x) / (H₀ + H₂x² + H₄x⁴ + ... + (H₁ + H₃x² + ...)x)
N and P are rational integral functions of x.
P equals the ratio of (G_0 + G_2x^2 + G_4x^4 + \cdots + (G_1 + G_3x^2 + \cdots)x) to (H_0 + H_2x^2 + H_4x^4 + \cdots + (H_1 + H_3x^2 + \cdots)x)
Multiplying both numerator and denominator by (H_0 + H_2x^2 + H_4x^4 + \cdots - (H_1 + H_3x^2 + H_5x^4 + \cdots)x) results in a new numerator and denominator containing only powers of x^2.

P equals the ratio of (M_0 + M_2x^2 + M_4x^4 + \cdots + (M_1 + M_3x^2 + M_5x^4 + \cdots)x) to (N_0 + N_2x^2 + N_4x^4 + N_6x^6 + \cdots) and is equal to a function of x^2 plus a function of x^2 multiplied by x.
V' = (x² dx)/R + (x³ dx)/R
R can always be assumed to be of the form (1 - x²)(1 - k²x²).
Putting x² = z, the second integral in Eq. (6) becomes (1/2) ∫ [z dz / ((1 - z)(1 - k² z))].
This integral can be integrated by the well-known methods of Integral Calculus, resulting in logarithmic and circular transcendentals.
There remains, therefore, only the form (x² dx)/R to be determined.
We will now show that R can always be assumed to be in the form (1 - x²)(1 - k²x²).
R = A x^4 + B x^3 + C x^2 + D x + E = G(x - a)(x - b)(x - c)(x - d), where a, b, c, d are the roots of the quartic polynomial and G is a constant (real or imaginary) depending on the coefficients.
Substituting x = (p + q y)/(1 + y) into equation (1) yields equation (7): V = (y, ) dy.
The radical is equal to G[p - a + (q - a)y][p - b + (q - b)y][p - c + (q - c)y].
The coefficients of odd powers of y under the radical must be zero to eliminate odd powers.
2pq - (p + q)(a + b) + 2ab = 0
2pq - (p + q)(c + d) + 2cd = 0
pq = (ab(c + d) - cd(a + b)) / (a + b - (c + d)), p + q = (2ab - 2cd) / (a + b - (c + d))
p and q are real quantities, regardless of whether the roots a, b, c, d are real or imaginary, with a, b and c, d being conjugate pairs.
equation (1) can always be reduced to the form of equation (7), which contains only the second and fourth powers of the variable.
R = G(x² - (a + b)x + ab)(x² - (a + b)x + cd) when a + b - (c + d) = 0
Substituting x = y - (a + b)/2 causes the odd powers of y to disappear.
For radical form G(x - a)(x - b)(x - c), substituting x = y² + a.
x = y^2 + a

G is a rational function of y

If we put x' = x - m, k² = -n m, we can reduce the radical to the form (1 - x²)(1 - k² x²).
The quantity k² is called the modulus and is real and less than unity.

The three types are called the three Elliptic Integrals of the first, second, and third kind, respectively.

chapter_4_\\Chapter{III}{Periodicity of.text: From equations II(7), II(8), II(9) of Chapter II, by substitution of (K) = 1, (K) = 0, (K) = k', we have equation (2).
These equations, by means of equations II(1), II(2), II(3) of Chapter II, give equation (3).
These, by changing u into u+2K, give equation (4).
Elliptic functions are periodic with period 4K.
Unlike the period of trigonometric functions, this period is not a fixed one, but depends upon the value of k, the modulus.
dφ = n dθ ± dθ₁, where θ is an angle between 0 and K, and the upper or lower sign is taken according as K is contained in an even or uneven number of times.
∫₀^{nθ + α} dφ = 2nK + ∫₀^α dθ₁, where θ₁ = φ - nθ
∫₀^{nθ - α} dφ = 2nK - ∫₀^α dθ₁, where θ₁ = nθ - φ
The integral with the general amplitude can be made to depend upon the complete integral K and an Integral whose amplitude lies between 0 and K.

Elliptic functions also have an imaginary period.
cos φ = sqrt(1 - k'^2 sin² ψ)
sn(iu ± iK') = -i sn(u, k') / cn(u, k')
cn(iu ± iK') = sn(u, k') / dn(u, k')
Substituting in these -iu in place of u, we get, by means of eqs. II(9) and eqs. II(14) of Chap. II
In these equations, putting u + K in place of u, we get
sn(u + K ± iK') = i k' cn(u) / dn(u)
sn(u + K ± iK') = ± i k' sn(u)
As u approaches zero, the expressions (±iK'), (±iK'), (±iK') approach infinity.
Elliptic Functions have two periods, one a real period, and one an imaginary period.
In the former characteristic they resemble Trigonometric Functions, and in the latter Logarithmic Functions.
On account of these two periods they are often called Doubly Periodic Functions.

Some authors make this double periodicity the starting-point of their investigations. This method of investigation gives some very beautiful results and processes, but not of a kind adapted for an elementary work.

The Elliptic Functions u, u, and u have a very close analogy to trigonometric functions, in which, however, the independent variable u is not an angle, as it is in the case of trigonometric functions.
Like Trigonometric Functions, Elliptic Functions can be arranged in tables requiring a double argument of u and k.
In Chapter IX, the functions are developed into series from which their values may be computed and tables formed.
No complete tables have yet been published, though they are in process of computation.

k and k', which are bound by the relation k^2 + k'^2 = 1, are called the primitives of the series.
The upper limit of the one series of moduli is 1, and the lower limit of the other series is 0, as is indicated.
It will be noticed that the successive terms of a decreasing series are indicated by the sub-accents 0, 00, 03, 04, 0n; and the successive terms of an increasing series by the sub-accents 1, 2, 3, n.

chapter_10_\\Chapter{XVII}{Applications..text: The polar equation of the Lemniscate is r² = a² cos 2θ, referred to the centre as the origin.
dr/dθ = -a² sin 2θ / r
s = ∫ sqrt( (dr/dθ)² + r² ) dθ
s = a ∫ sqrt(1 / cos 2θ) dθ
Let sin 2θ = t²
s = a \int \sqrt{1 - \sin^4 \theta}  d\theta
s = a \int \sqrt{1 + \sin^2 \theta}  d\theta
s = \frac{a}{2} \int_0^\phi \frac{d\theta}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{1}{2} \sin^2 \theta}}
s = \frac{a}{2} F\left(\phi, \frac{1}{2}\right)
r = a  2 = a
The angle θ can be easily constructed by describing upon the axis a of the Lemniscate a semicircle, and then revolving the radius vector until it cuts this semicircle.
In the right-angled triangle where the radius vector is one side and the axis is the hypotenuse, θ is the angle between the axis and the revolved position of the radius vector.
The equation of an ellipse is x²/a² + y²/b² = 1.
x = a cos θ, y = b sin θ, where θ is the complement of the eccentric angle.
s = ∫ √(dx² + dy²) = a ∫ √(1 - e² sin²θ) dθ = a E(e, θ)
The eccentricity e of the ellipse is the modulus of the Elliptic Integral.
The length of the Elliptic Quadrant is s' = a E(e, π/2).
For the ellipse x²/16.81 + y²/16 = 1, the arc length between abscissas 1.061162 and 4.100000 is 5.18912, and the quadrantal arc length is 6.36189.

The ordinate y of the hyperbola point is equal to b²/(a² + b²).
